item.title: Donald Trump and the White Man’s Burden in Nigeria
item.description: US President Donald Trump recently threatened to take military action against Nigeria to save Christians from a “genocide.” Trump has three possible motives for making such a threat: his mercantilist quest for rare-earth minerals, his pandering to evangelical Christians, and his racist grievances.

item.title: Global Health Workers Strengthen US National Security
item.description: The US government’s new global health strategy calls for shifting 270,000 frontline health-care workers from US-funded NGO programs to recipient government payrolls. But this could cause an exodus from the profession, undermining the disease-surveillance system and putting American lives at risk.

item.title: Trump’s Big, Not-So-Beautiful Economic Mess
item.description: Despite US President Donald Trump’s promises to lower inflation, shrink deficits, and revive manufacturing, his tariff wars have imposed steep costs on key allies, triggered price spikes, and hurt American producers and farmers. Yet there is little evidence that Trump is prepared to change course.

item.title: The AI War on Christmas
item.description: American politics has latched onto the idea that Christmas has somehow been sullied by foreigners, particularly non-Christians. In fact, the holiday has been corrupted by non-human entities: a set of algorithms that we flatteringly call artificial intelligence has desecrated the season’s music and holiday ritual.

item.title: PS Commentators’ Best Reads in 2025
item.description: As technological advances and geopolitical turmoil transform our economies, this year’s recommended books challenge prevailing assumptions and prompt us to reconsider what we take for granted. Ranging from scholarly analyses to literary fiction, they illuminate the choices that will define the years ahead.

item.title: America’s Civilizational Suicide
item.description: By heaping abuse on Europe and handling Russia and China with kid gloves, the Trump administration's National Security Strategy represents a radical departure from past US policies. But even as America rejects everything it once stood for, Europeans' only choice is to double down on their own principles.

item.title: Brazil’s Bold Industrial Turn
item.description: Despite strong opposition in Congress, Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has launched an ambitious industrial policy aimed at boosting renewable-energy capacity and expanding domestic defense capabilities. But sky-high interest rates and fiscal constraints risk putting these objectives out of reach.

item.title: The Transatlantic Rupture Is Complete
item.description: Under President Donald Trump, the United States is seeking to create a world order based solely on spheres of interest controlled by the US, China, and Russia. And because this will require breaking up the European Union, the decades-long transatlantic alliance has given way to enmity in remarkably short order.

item.title: Decision Time for Europe
item.description: Given the Trump administration’s recent statements and policy pronouncements, European leaders no longer have any excuse for failing to map out their own long-term security strategy. If they can get their act together on ending the Ukraine war, they will gain a much stronger position on other key fronts, too.

item.title: Beware of Central Economic Forecasts for 2026
item.description: In statistical terms, the coming year will offer a multi-modal distribution of possibilities: a plausible path of robust, AI-led growth sits in the middle, flanked by a productivity miracle on one side and a risk-laden, bond-market-led downside on the other. Investors and policymakers must prepare for all of these outcomes.

item.title: Institutional Redesign for Economic Change
item.description: Economics now recognizes the importance of institutions for growth, as evidenced by the winners of the Nobel Prize in economics for the last two years. And yet, the institutions that comprise innovation systems have become semi-fossilized in many countries, and policymakers rarely think about how to reform them.

item.title: Innovation that Works for Women
item.description: For decades, women have had to navigate systems and products that were not built with them in mind. Now, as research and investment finally begin to catch up, companies and investors need to recognize that meeting women’s needs is the right strategy for the bottom line.

item.title: The Worsening Geopolitics of Water in the Middle East
item.description: Countries across the Middle East are facing acute water shortages, owing to poor resource management, accelerating climate change, and regional power politics. In the absence of concerted diplomacy, water will soon be another flash point in a chronically unstable region.

item.title: How the Green Transition Can Support Africa’s Development
item.description: Despite its vast renewables potential, Africa’s clean-energy transition is being impeded by deepening economic and debt pressures. Any credible climate strategy must combine coordinated debt relief with growth-oriented, low-carbon investment that strengthens resilience and advances long-term national goals.

item.title: Peace as an Economic Strategy
item.description: It is no secret that wars have driven extraordinary innovation, generating everything from the radar to the internet. But far less appreciated is the extent to which peacemaking could bring the same level of resources and collective effort to bear on some of humanity’s greatest challenges.

item.title: Getting the AI Story Right
item.description: As AI moves from experimentation to real-world applications, the limits imposed by the physical world, capital markets, and political systems clearly matter more than its theoretical potential. Fortunately, such constraints are not hurdles to progress, but rather the scaffolding behind which it will take shape.

item.title: Antitrust Delayed Is Antitrust Denied
item.description: Meta’s recent antitrust win in a high-profile case brought by US regulators illustrates the challenges of reactive measures. Taking a preventive approach – namely, challenging mergers when they are first proposed – is a better way to prevent the emergence of monopolies in fast-moving tech markets.

item.title: Daddy Trump
item.description: In the 1970s, citizens of the Soviet Union scoffed at Leonid Brezhnev’s demented vanity, his insatiable need for praise, and the obsequiousness of his entourage. But it was nothing compared to the self-aggrandizing behavior of Donald Trump and the sycophancy of his enablers.

item.title: The Irresistible Temptation of Chile’s Polarized Politics
item.description: Four years ago, Chileans were tempted by the promise of a progressive “refoundation” of the country under Gabriel Boric, a former student leader, and elected him president. Now they have swung in the opposite direction, electing the far-right José Antonio Kast – and are likely to be equally disappointed.

item.title: The Post-Neoliberal Consensus Is Here
item.description: The best that can be said of Trump’s approach to the economy is that it is an experimental phase in the post-neoliberal transition. The good news is that future policymakers will not have to look far for new guiding principles.
